debate.title:
INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT (FAMILY TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996
FAMILY (TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by
Senator Campbell
:
That these bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased that I can speak on the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 and the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996. This is legislation that to some extent is positive for families, albeit fleetingly, before a range of other measures introduced by the government actually start to bite.

speech.para: This is legislation that is something of a novelty. After all, it actually delivers to some extent on one of the government's pre-election commitments. So many of the other pieces of legislation that we have been considering from this government not only break election commitments but also are anti-family. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996, Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996—just to mention some of the key bills that are before the parliament—are all decidedly anti-family and are all going in the direction of destroying the fabric of the social safety net that we in the Labor Party worked so hard for, not only in maintaining but in strengthening.

The family tax initiative was the centrepiece of the coalition's pre-election promises. The
coalition said this in its policy launch statement:

One of the greatest challenges of modern family life is to balance effectively work commitments and goals with family responsibilities and aspirations. Any credible family policy at a governmental level must be directed at helping families to achieve that balance. A Coalition Government will have this objective as one of its key priorities.

We will put the needs of families at the centre of national policy-making. We will reduce the economic pressures on families (especially those with dependent children). We will increase the opportunities open to them. And we will give them more genuine choices about how they live.

As much as the government might like us to, the family tax initiative cannot be considered on its own. It must be considered along with the other measures announced by the government in their budget and taken in the context of a budget that impacts so heavily and adversely on families, particularly low income families. I am not sure that the family tax initiative does much to help families `to balance effectively work commitments and goals with family responsibilities and aspirations'. I do know that the measures contained in the workplace relations legislation will work against any such balance.

As I said during the debate on that bill, the social costs of implementing the measures contained in the workplace relations legislation will have a devastating effect on families in Australia. It will dictate their level of income, their level of spare time and the way they manage their time—not only for themselves but for their families. Parents may have to work longer and more irregular hours, with less time to spend with their children and less capacity to organise adequate child care. Conditions such as paid holiday leave may be eroded. Weekend work may be foisted on workers. If maternity leave is written out of an agreement, women will be forced to return to their jobs or forced to give them up. The workplace relations legislation is a real Pandora's box of nasties that are not only anti-worker but anti-family.

The coalition claim that the family tax initiative will reduce the economic pressure on families. They also try to claim that it will increase the opportunities open to families
and give them more choices about how they live. However, the choice families are offered by the coalition is not about real choice and opportunities but about forcing people to choose what they can afford and what they can really do without.

Their claim of reducing economic pressures on families becomes a farce when considered in the broader budgetary context. What they are giving with one hand in the form of the family tax initiative, the Howard government is ripping away many times over on the other hand, despite John Howard's assertion that that is not the case. In fact, over the next four years, John Howard's broken promises will take over $17 billion out of the community. That is well over twice the amount of money that is being given back to the community in election promises.

The reality of the coalition's budget is that families will carry the greatest burden, even with this small bonus of the family tax initiative. They will face increased costs in child care, health and aged care and will bear the weight of reductions in funding for education, training and labour market programs. I ask: how can the family tax initiative be taken seriously when the government is at the same time pursuing so many other anti-family measures?

I would like to take longer than the time allowed for this debate to detail every measure that will adversely impact upon Australian families, but let me take the Senate through some of the more serious measures and the ones that I have particular interest in in the area of social security.

Probably the most serious betrayal of families is the cuts to child care announced in the budget by the coalition. The government has decided to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres. Soon community based long day care centres will have to face the choice of passing on the increased cost to parents withdrawing services such as baby places or extended hours or close. It is more choice, that is for sure, but none of them are attractive.

The decision not to provide capital funding to build 5,500 new long day care places means that these new places will simply not
be provided. The restricted eligibility for child care assistance fee relief and the application of a means test to the child‐care cash rebate will mean that almost all parents will face high out of pocket expenses for child care. Low income families will be hit the hardest, despite the coalition's commitment to protect the most vulnerable in our community. These costs alone will more than offset any extra money a family may get from the family tax initiative.

Despite promises to maintain all Commonwealth concessions, the government has provided no increase in the pharmaceutical allowance to offset the 50c per script increase in the prescriptions co‐payment. Families who benefit from concession cards will also have to pay $26 more each year for prescriptions for themselves and their children before they reach the safety net limit, when prescriptions become free and part of the family tax initiative will also have to pay for that.

You can add dental care to the coalition's bill for families. What has been widely condemned is a mean and completely unnecessary measure: the government has abolished the Commonwealth dental health program so that families who hold concession cards will no longer have access to free dental treatment for the whole family. For families with members in receipt of a pension or allowance, there are a number of measures that will increase the economic pressures on families even more and certainly reduce the opportunities open to them.

For parents returning to work or study, they will no longer receive the employment entry payment or the education entry payment. The abolition of the earnings credit scheme will remove incentives for many parents to take up part-time and casual work—flexible work arrangements that allow families to balance their work and family commitments. The pensions and allowances lump sum advance scheme need has been restricted so that families who need an advance on their pension or allowance to help them make larger purchases or pay off large bills may now find it harder to access that finance.

For families with one or more parents looking for work, the imposition of longer
waiting periods for unemployment payments will require parents to use up accrued leave such as long service leave and their savings before payments can be made. The government's vindictive measures to inflict harsher penalties for breaches of the activity test on unemployed people will leave many parents without any form of income support for long periods of time. Families will suffer.

There are also indirect burdens being placed on families. The increased charges and up‐front fees for nursing homes will place a large burden on families who, in a desperate attempt to get adequate care for their frail ageing relatives, may have to raise the money for significant entry fees or take on the burden of care themselves. On top of that, plans to offset the HACC program with increased user fees will hit the families of the people who benefit from HACC services. Mr Howard and Senator Newman have tried to woo families with this family tax initiative. However, as we start to add up the numbers we can see that the small benefits they are offering to families are totally eroded by their budget cuts.

I would also like to briefly raise a point that was detailed by my colleague Mark Latham in the House of Representatives. That is the issue of bracket creep. For every $1 through the family tax initiative, average PAYE tax paying families will lose another $8.30 in bracket creep taken away through gross PAYE tax collections as families move into higher tax brackets of taxation because the government will not introduce tax indexation. There does not seem to be much left over, if at all, from the family tax initiative.

Let me also say that this is not a simple piece of legislation. I do not hold it up as a piece of classic, clear, simple and accessible governance. Let me hasten to add that I do not in any way blame the drafters of the legislation for this. The policy that the coalition put to the electorate before the election was an extremely complex piece of policy. It has become more complex as the problems with the policy, for example, the income of the second earner, have seen the post‐election light of day.

break.para: On my part, and from the opposition's perspective, I believe this is a complex, unwieldy and unworkable system for delivering extra help to families. Let me give the Senate an example. Imagine you are a small business employing 20 people and every fortnight you calculate the amount of tax to deduct from their pay. At the moment this is based on how much you pay them less any rebates they might be eligible for. When this initiative is in place, the same employer will have to know for each of his or her 20 employees their domestic circumstances—how many children they have, how much their partner earns. It will be an administrative nightmare. This is from a government supposedly committed to reducing the administrative burden on small business.

The Labor Party has no amendments to the workings of this legislation and will not be supporting the amendments of the minor parties. This is clearly and solely the coalition government's mess. I, along with others on this side of the chamber, look forward to debating the amendments to the tax act the coalition will inevitably introduce to try to clean it up.

Clearly, the family tax initiative cannot make up for so many other measures that demonstrate the coalition's betrayal of the Australian people. They have broken promises. They have revealed their true colours on so many issues of importance to Australians. They courted voters giving them false hope and rhetoric about delivering to families, about protecting the poor, about protecting the needy and the most vulnerable in our community, about guaranteeing that no worker would be worse off under the new industrial relations legislation.

The measures contained in so many other bills before this parliament go to the heart of Australian families and diminish their capacity to live a decent life. The family tax initiative does not even go part way to compensate. The opposition will be moving an amendment to the second reading of the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 to reflect the points that I have been making which my other colleagues here will make soon and which have been made by
opposition speakers in the House of Representatives. I move the following amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate:

(1)
notes that only a limited proportion of family types receive the full benefits of the so‐called Family Tax Initiative;

(2)
expresses its concerns that other budget measures leave the average Australian family substantially worse off;

(3)
notes with concern that the Government is only returning to PAYE taxpayers a small proportion of bracket creep/fiscal drag revenue collections via this bill; and

(4)
expresses its concern that this and other Budget‐related measures have established very high effective marginal tax rates for non‐working parents returning to the workforce."

This amendment mirrors the one moved by the opposition in the House of Representatives. It reflects our belief and the increasing recognition in the Australian community that this budget takes from families a lot more than it gives in most cases.

This amendment raises four points. Firstly, it notes that only a limited proportion of family types receive the full benefits of the so‐called family tax initiative. The family tax initiative works out to $3.85 a week for each dependent child and an extra $9.60 a week if the family has a child under five. Couples are only eligible for this additional payment if the second partner earns no more than $4,535 a year.

The family tax payments are means tested. Families only receive the basic payment if their taxable income is less than $70,000, plus $3,000 for each child after the first child. The extra payment for children under five is only paid if the main breadwinner's annual income is less than $65,000, plus $3,000 for each child after the first child.

Instead of providing a rebate for this amount, the legislation takes the rather unusual step of adjusting the income tax free threshold by $1,000 for each dependent child under the first part of the concession and by $2,500 if the family has a child under five years old. This has the same effect as providing a rebate, but for some reason the government has decided on this unusual step. I
presume it is to reduce the comparison with the more generous family taxation rebates which applied under Labor, such as the spouse rebate, sole parent rebate, housekeeper rebate, the child component of the zone rebate and so on.

The second part of the opposition's amendment to the second reading expresses the Senate's concern that other budget measures leave the average Australian family substantially worse off. Of course, the Liberals hope that people will only notice the tax cuts that are written up in bold headlines and will miss all of the extra charges and cuts that are hidden away in the small print. Even after the cost of the family tax package is taken into account, the budget cuts $7.2 billion out of the economy over the next two years. No matter how John Howard and the Liberals try to hide it, the simple fact is that you cannot cut that much money out of the economy without having a big effect on ordinary Australians and their families.

Mr Howard has only been able to afford the family tax cuts and health rebates he promised in the election by making deep cuts to other services for Australian families. For every dollar that John Howard has given by meeting his election promises, $2.25 has been taken away by breaking promises alone. To make matters worse, the recent increases in the premiums charged by the health funds have substantially offset the benefit of the new rebates for private health insurance. While John Howard is giving tax cuts to families with one hand, the reality is that he is taking a whole lot more back with the other hand.

The third part of this second reading amendment is that the Senate notes with concern that the government is only returning to PAYE taxpayers a small proportion of bracket creep/fiscal drag revenue collections via this bill. As I said, the government is taking more in increases in PAYE taxation than it is returning to families by way of family tax relief and private health insurance. The budget papers show that gross PAYE receipts are to increase by 8.3 per cent this year. This represents an increase of $4.4 billion. This is an enormous slug on ordinary taxpayers and it compares with the total
amount being provided under the family tax initiative in 1996‐97 of under $400 million. Of course, there is no benefit flowing to families this year concerning private health insurance—only higher fees. Families know in this case that they are not better off.

Finally, this second reading amendment expresses its concern that this and other budget related measures have established very high effective marginal tax rates for non‐working parents returning to the work force. As I have said, taxation concessions are not phased out in the way that most social security benefits are. That is, they are either fully payable or not payable at all. I commend this second reading amendment to the Senate. Let us give this government a very clear message in relation to this bill and the broken promises of Mr Howard in his first short eight months in government.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

talk.start.para: —The bill we are debating does, as Senator Faulkner said, put into effect the government's pre‐election promise of a $1 billion family payments benefit. That is what it does on paper, but the Democrats seriously doubt whether the entire budget package—including the family tax rebate and all of the cuts to health, education, social security, child care, aged care, dental care and so on—results in any net benefit to families at all. Because what this government gives it is already taking away, even without the help of the private health insurers.

speech.para: The Democrats believe that the mechanism chosen by the government to effect this rebate is quite flawed. Senator Margetts has prepared an excellent paper on the inappropriateness of the design of this tax initiative. We think she is quite right to argue that the government is creating unnecessary complication by creating something new rather than building on the existing taxation rebate system. But the Democrats would go further than Senator Margetts and argue that the government should have built this rebate on top of the existing parenting allowance system.

We support the enactment of this pre-election promise but we do so with a little bit of reluctance because we remain unconvinced
that the best and fairest way of assisting Australian families is through tax relief. Secondly, we think that it is very poorly targeted. We said that in the pre-election campaign. The government made some corrections to its design, but we still think the effect is that it is poorly targeted, and I will expand on that in a moment. The third reason for our reluctance is that the government has failed to use the opportunity to fund this rebate from a crackdown on tax avoidance and family trusts.

All this adds up to a measure which, while offering some relief to low and middle income earners, and that has to be acknowledged, is also going to benefit some well off, even what we would consider rich, families at a considerable cost. We think that is the design flaw because we think that that cost could have and should have been avoided.

It is not particularly good public policy and it is not particularly good family policy when you can identify these flaws. What it is is a good bit of election pork‐barrelling. The problem is that it now has to be paid for. The great disappointment is that, instead of paying for it, as I said, through cracking down on tax avoidance, we all have to pay for it through cutbacks in other essential services and programs.

talk.start.para: —Yes, but that is not mutually exclusive, though.
—I think that is a very unfair choice. I think that is very badly designed, Senator Panizza.

speech.para: The Democrats are concerned obviously with how the rebate will be paid for. It has been funded entirely by cuts to social security programs. Half of the payment—that is, $483 million—turns up as an outlay under social security, as this will be the part paid to lower income families, rather than through the tax system. The total amounts of cuts to social security payments will be $957 million in 1997-98—paying for the entire family tax rebate.

Senator Faulkner already pointed to the inherent unfairness of taking money away from the unemployed, from the sick, from the aged, from migrants and from indigenous
Australians to fund a rebate which will flow to basically every family in Australia. That is what I am saying—at what cost?

Two‐income families end up about $3.75 a week better off; single‐income families are about $13.30 a week better off. That might look good on paper. It sounded good to people on budget night, but as the details have unravelled we have realised that that benefit will be more than wiped out by the loss of the Commonwealth dental program, the abolition of subsidies to community based child care, the increase in expenses under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the cuts to nursing home assistance if there is an aged member of the family, the massive hikes in HECS charges, the cuts to Austudy and social security payments, the cuts to labour market assistance if a member of the family is unemployed, the cuts to ATSIC if the family happens to be an indigenous family, the cuts to public schools funding and the cuts to public hospitals funding.

Families will need every single cent of their $3.75 benefit to pay for all those extra user charges. In most cases, particularly where the family does have an aged, sick, disabled or unemployed person, they are going to need a whole lot more than $3.75 to offset the money this government is taking away.

They call this a family budget, but as it unravels my feeling is that Australians will increasingly identify it as a `put your hand in the pocket for more money for families budget', because in fact it is anti‐family. People are not happy about getting $3.75 in one hand and, over the next two and three years, forking out five times that in order to keep up.

para.break: The Democrats think the rebate should have been paid for by cracking down on tax avoidance using artificial income splitting through family trusts and other artificial arrangements. We agree that PAYE taxpayers carry too heavy a load in our tax system. The government could easily find more than a billion dollars by paying closer attention to those higher income families who are splitting their income and rechannelling their income to reduce their tax. We think this would have made a fairer and far more supportable pack age than the route chosen by the government—paying for it by cutting assistance to the aged, the sick, the unemployed, the indigenous and the poor. Where is the family focus in that for goodness sake?

speech.para: We are also concerned at the way this rebate is quite poorly targeted—in other words, to whom it is paid. A two‐income family with three children could receive the full rebate with incomes of up to $79,000. About 95 per cent of families would receive that payment. The definition of income is taxable income, and that allows a whole range of tax planning loopholes to be used to reduce the income of a high income family sufficiently to pick up the payment.

It is just not well targeted enough. It is also confusing in that it adds several new thresholds, such as $65,000 for the part B benefit and $70,000 for the part A benefit, into the family payments area on top of the already established cut‐off for family payments of $63,766.

The Democrats think it would have been far simpler and fairer to base family tax payment eligibility on the family payment means test. If you had done that, the key differences would have been that it would start at incomes of $63,766 instead of $70,000, and that income would include a range of benefits high income earners take advantage of but which are not included in taxable income, such as not counting negative gearing losses, including any exempt foreign income and excluding households with assets of more than $500,000.

When these measures were introduced into the family payments system, they reduced the number of families receiving the payment by 10 to 15 per cent. That is a saving of, we think, about 10 per cent that is achievable here. That is $100 million. That is $100 million that the government would not have to squeeze out of other social security programs. I think it would be a much fairer targeting—particularly being mindful of what I have already said about how the rebate is being paid for—and I think it would be acceptable to families who already understand and use the family payments system.

break.para: However, we have had the election; we are eight months down the track. We remember this government chose to make this initiative the centrepiece of their pre‐election promises. They got the big impact then. They are just hoping that nobody is going to pay too much attention about how it is paid for down the track. They are hoping that everybody is going to forget about all the little bits and pieces in the budget as the months pass. They want to say, `We said we would do this for families and we are delivering on it.' At the most simple level, that will work. But at the important level of who pays for it, how it is targeted, what its design structure is, it is not a good piece of legislation and it is not a good piece of public policy. It is just a good piece of politicking, and you know it.

It is one of the $6 billion of core election promises being kept. That sounds good. Do not forget that there is $12.5 billion of non‐core—this new term we got after the election—election promises that have been broken in the first six months. The delivery mechanism, the targeting and the method of funding the tax rebate might be flawed. They have taken a risk. It is on the government's head. They clearly think the politics of it are worth it.

We support this bill with much reluctance. We think it could have been much better. We will support the opposition's second reading amendment because I think it does summarise the major flaws in this bill. It actually reflects the remarks that I have made in my speech.

It is interesting that this government paints itself as a pro‐family government. It is interesting that we are enacting this piece of supposedly pro‐family legislation. Let us wait for the proof down the track of what families end up with in their pockets as a result of this initiative offset by the whole budget. Let us not crow too early.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para:
—I say at the outset that our amendments do not represent our preferred option. The family tax initiative was a clear plank of coalition policy in the election. We do not have any objection to doing things for families and children, but we do question giving tax breaks and benefits to people at a
time when government is ruthlessly cutting out or cutting back basic services, such as the Commonwealth dental program, higher education funding and pharmaceutical benefits. If government is so concerned with debt and spending that it must cut into services that equitably provide basic services that people expect of government, I think it is hard to justify giving tax sweeteners without increasing revenue somewhere.

speech.para: At this stage, I mention that the opposition's second reading amendment will be supported by me, especially points 1 and 2 that note that only a limited proportion of family types receive full benefits of the so‐called family tax initiative, and that express concern—and this is a strong point, I believe—that other budget measures leave the average Australian family substantially worse off. I am less excited about points 3 and 4. I think they could be subject to debate but I believe the amendment is worthy of support and it is very important that those messages, especially the messages embodied in sections 1 and 2, get sheeted home to the government.

I also have very basic problems with making things more complicated than necessary, especially the administration of tax and social security. If government wanted to grant a benefit, it could have added an extra $7.70 to the fortnightly family payment or, if it wanted a more targeted benefit, it could have added the $7.70 per fortnight to the additional family payment. This would have been straightforward and administratively simple. That is why I say this is not our preferred option. The disadvantage is that $7.70 per fortnight or $3.85 per week does not sound so enticing when compared to the draconian social policy of this government. But in real terms, this is what the family tax initiative will provide.

Instead of taking the simple route, this government chose to make their sweetener sound artificially large. By changing tax thresholds, they could make what is effectively a $200 rebate into a $1,000 handout to families. Of course, reading bottom line figures, that is 20 per cent of $1,000—$1,000 times the lowest marginal ordinary income tax rate.

break.para: In doing this, the government made the choice to add administratively to social security by adding a third form of family payment, with a third set of applications and administration. It also started messing with income tax rates thresholds, making them vary with the particulars not only of individual taxpayers but also their families.

I predict that this will create immense difficulties for the tax office, not only in calculating this but also in getting all the requisite information not only about a taxpayer but also about their family. I further predict that the cost of administering this scheme in the way government set it out will be substantial, and personally, I wonder whether $7.70 a fortnight in benefit will justify the cost of setting up two new structures to administer it.

Our preferred option would have been the simplest one—delivery of the benefit through one of the two existing systems of family payment. But the government has said that the basis of their scheme is clear. I know the opposition, while sympathising, feels it cannot make such radical changes in a scheme which the current government took to the polls. So our amendments do not represent our preferred option. The course we have taken is to try to preserve the government scheme, while transferring the tax treatment to a more workable form.

The Greens (WA) amendments have an effect on the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 in two ways. First of all, they recreate the effect of the government bill in the Income Tax Assessment Act, rather than in the Income Tax (Rates) Act, which has significant effects in terms of simplifying taxation law and self‐assessment difficulties. Secondly, they create a taper for the rebates, rather than having a sharp cut‐off.

The effect of our amendment of the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 is mainly to make consequential amendments related to the change in the income tax rates bill. There is also an amendment to change the term `breadwinner' to `primary income partner' and `breadwinner's partner' to `lower income partner', and another change to eliminate sexist language by
deletion of the reference to `opposite sex' from one of the definitions.

By adding approximately two pages of text to the Income Tax Assessment Act, rather than over 20 pages to the Income Tax (Rates) Act, the Greens amendment preserves the rationale of tax legislation while reducing difficulties. The Income Tax (Rates) Act is a simple act designed to set the various rates at which different classes of taxpayers pay tax. This is the act that states the tax rates for residents, non‐residents, and so on. As such, the act is clear and straightforward. When a person moves from one class to another—for example, when a non‐resident taxpayer returns to residency—formulae are needed to assess their tax rates for the whole of the year. This act also provides such formulae.

The Income Tax (Rates) Act was never designed to provide means of altering the rates with regard to specifics of individual taxpayers, the number of dependants, whether those dependants have incomes, and so on. This act has no provisions for dealing with taxpayers other than as broad classes. The purpose of this bill is to set the tax rates for those classes. It is the Income Tax Assessment Act which was designed to deal with all the individual variations of conditions for taxpayers. It is this act that determines deductions, exemptions, benefits, rebates and so on. It is this act that specifies when an individual taxpayer is assessable or exempt and under what conditions or variations. It is this act which defines things like eligibility of specific dependants and treatment of spouse income. It is the Income Tax Assessment Act which is the act under which the family tax initiative should occur.

Taxation law is already immensely complex and convoluted. It makes no sense at all to make it more so. The rates act has never been used in this way. To do so now will set a precedent and we may begin to see the rates act further modified to deal with a range of issues, individual variations, benefits and political promises. It is an attractive option, when a $200 rebate can be sold as a $1,000 gain in the tax‐free threshold. So it is about politics and selling a message, and it is about politics and disguising a message.

The effect of this is to require the definition within the rates act of a range of particulars of eligibility, conditions and so on, duplicating what is already effectively in the assessment act. It also requires immensely convoluted methods where income thresholds may be moved far enough to shift the tax‐free area into higher marginal tax rates.

We see this in this bill, where government, to preserve the equality of the $200 rebate have, for example, had to create a 14 per cent margin for those who, through having over 14 eligible child dependants, might have shifted the threshold for the 15th child from the 20 per cent margin to the 34 per cent margin. Also, because rates vary with classes of taxpayer, complex formulae for calculating partial rates with movement of rates thresholds had to be provided, essentially with no purpose other than to preserve the benefit as a $200 rebate, rather than a legitimate change to the threshold of whatever system of rates the taxpayer was paying under.

It is, as the Greens amendments show, far more simple and straightforward to call a rebate a rebate and put the changes under section 159J, which already deals with child and student rebates. This has the political disadvantage of stating clearly what is being done and making clear that this re‐establishes child rebates, which were discontinued in 1976. It also draws attention to the fact that the level of child rebates currently listed under the act, though unpaid, are $376 for the first and $282 for subsequent children, while the new rebate is only $200.

Child rebates were discontinued in 1976 in favour of child endowment which later became family payments and are paid through social security. They benefit those whose income is too low for them to benefit from a tax rebate. We see this government not only attempting to recreate the child rebate but also creating within social security a third family payment called the family tax payment. In our opinion, that is unnecessarily duplicative legislation. In point of fact, the entire family tax initiative could have been achieved by adding $3.85 per week or $7.70 per fortnight to the current family payment, instead of
giving any tax rebate, with a great deal less administrative expense.

On the issue of compliance, the government is certainly adding an additional burden on the Australian Taxation Office which must try to assess, simply, this shifting threshold model. Since taxpayers, under self‐assessment are ultimately liable for mistakes and are assumed to have knowledge of the law, this also creates a burden on taxpayers. Where a rebate can be simply handled by the addition of an extra line under the rebates section, the government method entails giving various confusing formulae for anyone who is not in the simple resident PAYE taxpayer class.

I feel the government approach is messy, inappropriate and liable to increase costs and problems. It opens up a whole new range of tax manipulations through threshold changes. I personally, and the Greens (WA), favour reducing the complication of the tax system, particularly where self‐assessment will create problems for taxpayers. I feel my amendments are far more appropriate than the government bill and urge other parties to support them.

While table 2 in section 159J of the Income Tax Assessment Act is referred to in other portions of the act, and in other legislation, I have not found any cases where the amounts of rebate have been referred to. Only the class of rebates, which have been preserved, is referred to in any legislation we have seen so far. If there are implications within other pieces of legislation, we think they could be subsequently addressed through consequential amendments.

I have also applied the idea of tapers, already included in dependent rebates and family payment. I will cover that in more detail in the committee stage of the bill. While I think they are a good idea, I am willing to concede to their amendment if it means that my amendments will be accepted. So I am happy to break up my amendments so that we can vote on them separately.

My amendments do not seek to improve the intent of the government's scheme more than marginally. I understand that such a change would not get support. Our amendments are intended to at least save the nation from tax legislation that will be difficult to administer
or is possibly unworkable. They are intended to ensure that in starting new programs we do not dramatically increase the complexity, administration and compliance costs of tax legislation.

I understand that other parties accept the notion of an effective child rebate as proposed by the government. We, too, accept that there will be benefits to average families, particularly under the part A scheme. Some families, including some poor families, may benefit from the part B scheme, too, in spite of its obvious bias towards certain social groups. But I cannot sit still and allow legislation as badly designed as this to go out of this place without at least making an effort to make it workable.

I realise, from the words so far of other senators, that it might be an object lesson for the government to allow them to stew in their own juice, to create a system which is unworkable and see how they are going to fight their way out of it. In some ways it is analogous to the situation with the ATSIC bill where I pointed out to the minister that, in their efforts to try to change the election while it was happening, they had changed the eligibility criteria. We pointed out the problem and saved the government, the taxpayer and ATSIC millions of dollars in trying to sort out the problem later.

We are making the effort, we have made the gesture, and it is open for the government to accept it. It is open for other senators to accept it. I urge other parties to support our amendments in the committee stage. I also understand the feeling that, if the government is going to be so stupid in doing something for a political advantage, people would like to see them take the rap for the stupidity of their approach.

talk.start.para: —We do not oppose this bill, but we certainly have major reservations about it. I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Faulkner. The government has attempted a sleight of hand in this budget and also in this bill. It has promoted the family tax initiative as a bonus for the families of Australia and New South Wales, the state that I represent.

break.para: This tax initiative is not an adequate compensation for the massive cuts in services and the increased costs that the people of Australia will have to face as a result of what this government has done. Essentially, the proposed plans provide families with a means tested $3.85 a week extra in the pocket for each dependent child by increasing the tax free threshold.

Let us get a real grasp of the generosity of this $3.85. If you are lucky, for $3.85 you can get an extra loaf of bread and two litres of milk. Such is the generosity of this government to families. It gives a family an extra $9.60 if it has a child under five and the second partner earns less than $4,500 a year. The families of New South Wales would require a much higher payment than this just to retain their present position. It is very small compensation for the cuts to services that this government introduced in its budget and for the increased costs in health, child care, education and a vast array of other areas.

The family tax initiative fails to deliver real benefits to the families of Australia. It fails to improve the financial position of families. In fact, as a result of this bill and the budget, families in Australia are worse off. The coalition offered, with a lot of fanfare and razzamatazz, the family tax initiative even though it does not come close to compensating for those extra costs.

The coalition further said in its policy document that a coalition government will work to maintain and strengthen the central role of the family in our society. The Treasurer (Mr Costello), in his second reading speech on this bill, said:

The family tax initiative is a clear example of the government's commitment to giving families greater choice in how they spend their hard‐earned cash and in how they juggle work and family responsibilities.
I will come back to this issue later and show that it is really a complete fallacy.

The coalition has failed on both these counts. The family tax initiative does very little to strengthen the central role of the family in our society. It is a moderate increase in the tax free threshold which does
not, as I have said, compensate for the extra cost imposed by this government.

Part A of the proposal provides an increase in the tax free threshold of $1,000 for each dependent child, and they must be under 14 or up to 18 in full-time education. Families that earn less than $70,000 will get $3.85 a week for each dependent child. Part B of this initiative will provide one income families where one parent earns up to $65,000 and there is at least one child under five with an additional increase in the tax free threshold of $2,500. So that is $3.85 plus $9.60—not really a very princely sum, is it?

If there are two parents, the second can earn only $4,500 to be eligible, which means that any family where the second person is working more than a few hours a week is automatically excluded. In fact, only 13 per cent of families in Australia are eligible under part B of this initiative. I think that is a pretty clear statement of the fact that this government is out of touch. When it talks about battlers, it really does not know whom it is talking about because it thinks that the battlers, the mainstream of Australia, are this small group of 13 per cent that it said are the real Australians.

What families are facing, which outweighs the benefit of anything contained in this package, are greater costs—greater costs brought about by decisions of this government. Let us have a look at the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The government has increased charges under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme—$2.60 for every prescription for all families. Even the less well off in community and the vulnerable in our community—pensioners and health card holders—have to pay an additional 50c per script.

Not only that, but this government has also broken the nexus between the pharmaceutical allowance provided to social security recipients and the additional cost paid for pharmaceuticals. So the government has said, `As we no longer accept that we have a responsibility to cover the costs of those vulnerable and older people in our community, we have broken the nexus.'

I go back to families. A family can often have a number of children sick at the same
time if they have caught something like mumps or measles, which are still quite common diseases these days, and it may have to fill up to three scripts. That family would have to pay $60 out of their pocket extra to what they would have had to pay previously.

Child care is an issue of great concern to families at large—a principle that this government seems to have discarded. The fact is that the majority of families have both people in work—in fact, over 50 per cent. That is the norm in Australia these days. Child-care costs will now rise because of decisions that the Howard government has made. Families who have children in community based child-care centres will be paying an additional $25 to $30 a week for each of those children. The quality and availability of child care will decline and parents will have fewer choices.

The sad thing about the undermining of the community based child-care sector is that community based child-care centres play two important roles—they are very important for me as a parent and, I think, for most parents. One is that they are a check on the quality of care and the other is that they do the most to provide child care for children under two years of age. If you have a very young child, you will know how very difficult that is.

The government has cut $500 million from expenditure on child care. The government has also tightened eligibility for child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. The government has also overturned the hard-won principle that child care is a legitimate work related expense by introducing a means test on the child-care rebate. There is no means test for other work related expenses, such as books or tools, but women in the work force who have to take up child care do have a means test imposed.

Let us look at the changes that have been imposed by this government in the area of nursing homes. It is a very hard decision for a family when they believe that a parent or an elderly relative has reached the stage where they should be placed in a nursing home. It is a time of great emotional difficulty and soul searching. This is difficult enough, but
the financial changes that have been brought about in this budget make it even more difficult.

During the estimates hearings of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee in answer to a question on notice, the Department of Health and Family Services indicated that entry fees in hostels were on average $30,000 in New South Wales. This is the model that it is adopting for nursing homes now. In fact, the department estimated that Australia‐wide the average fee for entry into nursing homes would be $26,000. That is a fee that before the election of this government people did not have to pay.

The government has not placed a limit on this fee that the vulnerable family in search of a place for their elderly relative has to pay. There is no limit. It says that there is a de facto limit of $88,000. To me that is pretty steep and I do not think many people in the community would see that as reasonable. But that is not where the pain ends for those people who have a relative they need to place in a nursing home.

If you earn a small amount over the pension, then you have to pay a fee of $34 a week—$12,000 a year—for the privilege of being in a nursing home. That is a privilege you had for free before the election of this government. It is not just the elderly person who bears the cost; it is the whole family who bears the cost.

The government's justification in imposing these fees is, `They have them in hostels so why not in nursing homes?' But the fact is that the entry to a hostel is a choice that you have. In most cases, people do not have a choice about entering a nursing home. They are physically frail, they are ill and they do not have the support at home to remain there because of the extent of their frailty so it is compulsory for them to enter a nursing home. It is brought about by necessity. The government has chosen in these circumstances to impose these sorts of fees.

I will now go on to the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program, which really, for all the things that were expected from a conservative coalition government, shocked even us. It shocked us that you
should see fit to abolish a program that provides dental care for those people who really are struggling out there in the community. You have said that these people are not entitled to dental care. I visited a dental health clinic the other day. I have to confess that there were not many silvertails out there. There were people in their 70s and 80s with bad teeth, some of them trying to get their teeth repaired and some of them needing false teeth. A couple of dozen of them sat out there waiting for some treatment which they would not be able to obtain at any other place because they cannot afford it.

But this government saw fit to abolish that program. Previously you could get emergency care in a dental health clinic, usually within 24 hours, at the maximum three days, and you could get the run‐of‐the‐mill routine dental care in about eight weeks. But what is the situation now? You wait up to two weeks for emergency care and you are on the waiting list for routine care. By Christmas the waiting list is estimated to be two years. The reality of that is that there is no routine dental care for the elderly and the vulnerable in our community because of this government's decision.

The dental health cuts have already had a major impact. We have seen the other bonuses being offered by the government—the private health insurance rebate. What a great idea! Nobody has the benefit of that yet. It will come in about 1 July next year and is about $400 for a family. But already half of that rebate has been lost by increases in premiums for health insurance that this government has approved. So that particular budget item is a big zero for families.

On top of the particular items I have had the opportunity to outline in detail, there are higher university costs, cuts to funding to government education and more costs associated with health and child care. In fact, there will be major increases in fees and charges imposed by state governments because of the run-on effect of cuts and decreases to payments to the states. A family with at least one child in a community child-care centre and a parent in a nursing home will be paying an additional $100 a week because of decisions
made by this government. If you happen to be a health card holder, you are even worse off each week.

I guess I have to feel sorry for the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer who have to sell a deal where they say, `We'll give you $3.85 and we'll take $100; that is a pretty good deal.' If they manage to sell that, they are doing pretty well. Certainly, it is not a deal that most families in Australia who have pretty good commonsense would accept.

There is a further aspect of this bill that I find particularly concerning. This family tax initiative is an attempt at social engineering. It clearly indicates there is a preferred model of family. It does not accept that there is a wide array of families where family members have made different choices about their roles and their lifestyles. It says that there is only one particular valid model and that is the one that is indicated by this bill.

I believe families, in all their diversity, are a caring and valid vehicle for the care of all their members. I believe all children, in no matter what type of family, are entitled to care, protection and assistance. Thankfully, the government has made some changes to their proposal. Initially, a family was to be excluded from any benefit if the non-bread winning spouse earned any income at all—that is, income from their actual effort, if they were working income earners. But for people who did not earn income by their own sweat, if they had up to $20,000 of unearned income, that was all right; they could still get the benefit. Thank goodness they saw the error of their ways in relation to that. I applaud that change. The government has now said that the non-bread winning spouse can earn up to $4,500.

Under this bill, the situation is that a two-income family with two dependent children under the age of five receives no assistance under this proposal if one person is earning $39,000 and the other is earning, say, $36,000. In fact, they will be paying, as I have said, approximately an additional $100 a week because of this government's decision. But, alternatively, a one-income family with the father earning $68,000, for example, with two dependent children under five gets $17 a
week extra and does not pay any additional child-care costs.

This is a gap between the two families of about $70 a week just because they made different lifestyle choices and the second family did not conform with the appropriate model according to this government. But I guess that really does not come as a big surprise to a lot of people. A very interesting study called the Australian candidate study released recently revealed that 33 per cent of coalition candidates in the last election believed that Australia had gone too far in providing equal opportunities for women and 40 per cent did not believe the government should increase opportunities for women in business and industry. I guess this package brings about the effect of a lot of those candidates' views—that women had it too good under the previous Labor government and it is about time that process was reversed.

We do not oppose this bill. We want to make it clear to the community that it is a farce—that you get $3.85 and they take $100 out of your back pocket. We do not believe that is a particularly good deal.

speech.speaker: Bishop, Sen Mark

talk.start.para: —It is very interesting that we are discussing today the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996. I have just been handed a photograph of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer). It shows him dressed in fish‐net stockings and leopard skin stiletto heels. He displays a most charming and coy manner to the camera—it is truly attractive. In the context of recent amendments moved to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, and matters foreshadowed by Senator Margetts less than half an hour ago on transgender and cross‐dressing issues, I am sure the Liberal Party and their friends in the National Party will be more than pleased to support those amendments on the issue of transgender identity in due course. Nonetheless, I want to address more serious issues in this chamber than are apparent elsewhere—
—We are hoping you will do that.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Howard government's family tax initiative must not be examined as a separate initiative designed to assist Australian families; it should be looked at in terms of the overall Howard budget. It is in this light that the real intent of the budget is clear. The family tax initiative is little more than a smokescreen to disguise other attacks on workers and their families. The tax initiative seeks to claim that the government is making Australian families far better off. This $3.85 per week is supposedly to make up for the evils of the first government budget.

speech.para: When one looks though at other changes proposed in the budget, one becomes increasingly aware that the cover‐up attempted by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) cannot be allowed to continue. There are a series of significant problems and deceptions in Mr Howard's family tax initiative which are apparent in the following areas: the initiative's lack of support for families when considered against changes to child care; the initiative's lack of support for families when considered against changes to aged care; the initiative's lack of support for families when considered against changes to general health care; the initiative's lack of support for families when considered against government allowed increases in private health insurance premiums; the initiative's lack of support for families when considered against previous Labor government tax rebates designed to support families; and the initiative's lack of support for families when considered against state grants cuts attacking state hospitals and schools.

The family tax initiative will give families $3.85 per week for each dependent child. An extra $9.60 per week will granted where families have a child under the age of five. Importantly, the proposal really only deals with the granting of $3.85 per week. This is because at best only 13 per cent of the Australian community will be eligible for the second part of the offer. Why? The government has placed a $4,500 threshold on the second income earner. This threshold will easily be reached if a part‐time or casual worker works nine to 10 hours on a Thursday
night and a Saturday. The result? The exclusion of these families from the second rung of the offer.

As previous mentioned, the tax initiative is really a deception. It gives with one hand and it takes with the other. The proposal means little when compared to the changes to child care made by Mr Howard. The proposed child care changes will take from families much more than the family tax initiative will give. This deception occurs in a number of ways. As members in the other place have already pointed out, the extra costs for families due to cuts in child care support by Mr Howard far exceed the benefit of the family tax initiative. A recent EPAC study on child care estimates that the cost of the cut proposed by the government in the operating subsidy for community based child care will cost families $21.40 per week for children under three and $14.35 per week for children older than three.

The cuts are just as draconian for private child care. This side of the chamber has calculated that a family on an annual income of about $30,000 and with two children in long day care for 50 hours per week, will pay an extra $19.60 per week. If the same family earns $45,000 per year, they will pay $15.30 extra per week in child care fees. The result is that for low income families the $3.85 thrown at them by the Prime Minister through the family tax initiative compares very poorly with the $21.40 he intends to take away from them through additional child care costs.

The deception of this initiative does not stop at child care; the elderly are not safe from the attacks of the Howard budget. The changes in this area have already been much publicised and attacked by the Labor Party and the community in general. However, they still deserve a mention in passing. Mr Howard will charge the elderly $34 per day for nursing home fees. This is in addition to the $26,000 up‐front entry fee now proposed by the government. Unfortunately, the attacks on the elderly do not stop there. The Commonwealth dental program, which the Prime Minister promised to maintain at its real value, has been cut by the budget. The result will be an increase in waiting lists for health care card holders. Prescription prices for
health care card holders will also increase. This increase will mean that prescriptions will cost an additional 50c, so the price will rise from $2.70 to $3.20. Home and community care programs will move toward a user‐pays system.

Twenty per cent of the cost of home care will have to be paid for by those who most need the care. This will affect programs such as meals on wheels, which will cost anywhere between $4 per hour and $6.30 per hour. For an elderly person who has three meals on wheels per week at the upper limit of $6.30 per hour, there will be cost of approximately $1,000 per year. This will also have an impact on the family tax initiative for children: it will mean that couples with elderly parents will dig into their own pockets to ensure their parents are adequately looked after. The cost will be far greater than the miserable $3.85 per week that Mr Howard will throw at them. If couples have to find $34 every day to ensure adequate care for their elderly parents, the $3.85 from the family tax initiative can only be considered a sick joke.

There are number of other health cuts which take from families who have children more than the family tax initiative will give. As already outlined, the cost of prescription drugs for families will increase from $17.40 to $20. Hospital funding grants to the states will also be cut. Additionally, the cost of eye, knee and appendix operations will increase. The increase in the cost of prescription drugs leaves $1.25 for the family from the tax initiative. However, the damage goes even further. As anyone with children knows, kids get sick at the same time. Consequently, the caring parent usually catches the virus. Prescription medicine for the sick children and the carer will cost the family no less than $80 in one hit. God help them if the prescription requires repeats.

Add this to the fact that bulk‐billing is in danger due to the government's failure to adequately compensate doctors and the health rebates being eroded by government sponsored premium increases in health insurance, the availability of medicine becomes a questionable issue. As just mentioned, private health insurance premiums will also take more
from families than the Howard tax initiative will give back. The family tax initiative will in no way encourage participation in private health insurance nor will it go in any way towards assisting with the increased premiums from the major funds that the government has allowed and supported. These increases put the final nail in the coffin when it comes to Mr Howard's attack on health care for families.

How will these increases affect families? For example, a couple in New South Wales, who will get a rebate from the government for private health insurance, will have their premiums increased by $306. Two‐thirds of this $450 rebate will be wiped out for families with dependent children. These increases destroy any benefit from the private health insurance tax rebate. When comparing the increase of the health insurance premium to the health rebate, the $3.85 per week family tax initiative does not even deserve a mention.

The introduction of the tax initiative by way of increasing the tax free threshold is curious in itself. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition summed it up best when he surmised that even if it were introduced as a rebate, it would of course be compared with all other rebates—those introduced by the previous Labor government. When compared with these, the Howard rebate would appear pathetic. All of these increases far exceed any moneys given to families through the family tax initiative. The Howard government will attempt to deceive the Australian people by taking up the $3.85 per week family tax initiative. Meanwhile, they publicly ignore the child‐care cuts, the health care cuts, the aged care cuts and the increases in private health insurance premiums, while the office of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) gleefully adds up all they have taken from Australians.

These cuts mentioned are, of course, just the tip of the iceberg. There are a number of other areas in which the federal government has made cuts destroying the credibility of assistance through the tax rebate. These all destroy any assistance that the $3.85 per week tax rebate would provide. For example, in relations between the Commonwealth and the states, there has been an enormous reduction
in the grants made to the states. The result of this will be to reduce the quantity and quality of services that the states are able to provide. Areas such as hospitals, schools and TAFEs will be affected. Already in some states primary schools have leased some of their land to groups such as mobile phone companies for aerial reception purposes just to raise enough money to pay the school's daily bills.

With the cuts to state grants by the Commonwealth, this situation can only get worse. States such as New South Wales, for example, are already grappling with the problem of federal funding being insufficient for service provision. In New South Wales, Mr Carr has been forced to introduce the Howard‐Costello tax in a number of areas just to continue current essential service provision in that state. These increases have occurred in areas such as land tax, payroll tax and stamp duties on motor vehicles.

Mr Howard and Mr Costello do not escape criticism from their colleague Mr Kennett and his government either, although this is nothing new. The Victorian government has been forced to postpone tax cuts in that state in order to pick up the tab left by the cuts in funding by the federal government. I will repeat a quote of Alan Stockdale, the Victorian Treasurer, already made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) in the House of Representatives. Mr Stockdale said:

These burdens flow through to State taxpayers and they'll have to fund these burdens, and Mr Costello is taxing them by stealth in flagrant breach of his election commitment, upon which he was elected with an overwhelming mandate by the people.
If this coalition government has any mandate at all, it is not to slash services provided to our community by the states.

What has been the Prime Minister's response to these concerns and criticisms? In question time in the House of Representatives on Monday he castigated the opposition for daring to say that a package of $3.85 per week, while all the other costs previously mentioned are increasing, was not enough for Australian families. The Prime Minister believes that $3.85 per week is an excellent
return to the Australian community for the suffering that will be inflicted by the other wide range of cuts proposed by his government. Clearly, the Howard family tax initiative can be seen as nothing more than a deception of the Australian community.

The wide range of cuts mentioned in health care, aged care, child care, higher education, private health insurance increases and cuts to the states, which will affect schools and hospitals just for starters, are all devastating on their own. As a combination, as Mr Howard has surely intended them to be in order to increase tax receipts, they will push many families over the edge. The quality of the lifestyle and the quality of education and health care for their children will be greatly decreased.

The devastation of these cuts and the impact they are about to have is evident in my home state of Western Australia. Anticipating the full impact of the Howard budget cuts and the cuts in federal grants to be realised in early 1997, the Premier, Mr Court, has called an unprecedented early Western Australian election in an attempt to avoid any political backlash that will stem from the cuts and Mr Court's support of them. By calling an early election before Christmas—the first since 1905 in Western Australia—Mr Court will avoid the commencement of the Howard budget cuts coinciding with the state election campaign. This is a further example of state Liberals attempting to distance themselves from Mr Howard's budget.

The family tax initiative cannot be considered a supportive step for Australian families and the Australian community. It will provide little solace for those bearing the full brunt of Mr Howard's budget cuts. That is why it is a deception. However, its attempt to cover up the broad range of cuts only serves to allow the opposition a chance to highlight the severity of the cuts even further.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para:
—I am delighted to close the debate on the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 and the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996. I wish to thank all the contributors for their contributions, although they were of varying
quality. Some, particularly the last ones, seemed to be more concerned to get a few issues up on the state election front rather than make a serious analysis of the bills.

speech.para: These bills give legislative effect to the family tax initiative, the centrepiece of the coalition's family package, to ease the tax burden on low and middle income Australian families with children. Lower income families will have the alternative of the fortnightly cash assistance. The initiative recognises the cost of raising families and offers families a choice in whether one parent wants to stay at home and care for children.

The coalition framed the policy to acknowledge the central importance of the family and to give them hope for the future after 13 years of Labor policies and neglect. Consistent with our election policy, the initiative is being delivered as an increase in tax-free thresholds rather than as a tax rebate, the alternative which is preferred by the Greens. The initiative will give a major boost to almost two million Australian families with dependent children and is being delivered in full and on time. The initiative is a $1 billion a year direct injection into the pockets of Australian families starting on 1 January 1997, which makes the comments that Senator Bishop just shared with the chamber even more curious.

There are two methods of delivery for the family tax initiative: first, through the income tax system as adjustments to the tax‐free threshold called the family tax assistance; and, second, low income families will receive the family tax initiative as a direct fortnightly payment, called the family tax payment, from the Department of Social Security. Some 900,000 families will receive an immediate boost to their disposable income through this measure.

para.break: During the debate of the bills in the House, a number of incorrect statements were made by members of the opposition about the family tax initiative. I would like to take this opportunity to briefly dispel some of the myths that have been peddled by the opposition. Firstly, let me reassure the Senate that the family tax assistance will benefit around two million Australian families with children out of some 4.9 million families with chil dren. The cost of the initiative is about $1 billion in a full year. The cost is made up not only of the cost of the increased tax threshold but also of the family tax payment paid through the Department of Social Security.

speech.para: Secondly, some members of the opposition—most notably the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans); the shadow assistant treasurer, the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham); and the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence)—have also incorrectly claimed that part B of family assistance will benefit only 13 per cent of families. They are unable to do simple maths. They seem to have inadvertently omitted that low income families will receive cash payment from the DSS instead of tax assistance, as they have excluded single-income families. If you eliminate the opposition's errors, using their figures 27 per cent of families will be eligible for part B assistance, not 13 per cent. When you compare this with the total families with children, the percentage is 54. Even higher is the percentage of families with children under five.

Thirdly, contrary to statements by the member for Werriwa that single parents do not qualify for part A of the benefits, they indeed do, provided the family income test is met. Single parents may qualify for both parts A and B.

talk.start.para:
—Did you read this in the House of Representatives
Hansard
?

—Yes, I do read the
Hansard
of the other place, even the odd speech by members of your own side. The family tax initiative recognises that not all Australian families are identical. It recognises the wide range of family structures in Australia. As well as nuclear families, it accommodates sole parents, grandparents caring for grandchildren and foster families. However, part B of the initiative provides additional assistance to those with young families. We make no apologies for that extra help.

speech.para:
Not surprisingly, members of the Labor Party also made some unfounded assertions that the government has given a few dollars with the family tax initiative but taken back a lot more with the budget. That was a theme raised by a number of opposition senators.
Firstly, and most importantly, the budget was carefully designed to rein in the large budget deficit created by 13 years of Labor fiscal irresponsibility. Labor failed the task of reducing its budget deficit to a sustainable level. As a result, families have been forced to pay higher interest rates than they otherwise should, and more and more of the taxes paid by ordinary Australians must be used to pay the interest on government debt.

The government's deficit reduction program is an integral part of its ongoing commitment to families. Already, Australian families are benefiting from falls in interest rates. Lower mortgage repayments are substantially benefiting families across Australia, leaving more money for other expenses. Lower interest rates will also assist families who are in small business and who are primary producers.

Our industrial relations reforms will lead to more real jobs for Australians: jobs for mums and dads and young Australians. In the budget, we also honoured our election commitment to make private health insurance more affordable for lower and middle income earners. From 1 July 1997, families with dependent children with private health insurance will benefit from an incentive of up to $450 per year provided as a reduction in premiums or as a tax rebate. We have maintained Medicare in its entirety, including bulk-billing.

The government has demonstrated its commitment to affordable, flexible and high quality child care. The government's child-care package will provide greater choice for families. We have allocated $256.6 million over four years to retain the operational subsidy for family day care. We have provided $195 million over four years to retain the operational subsidy for occasional and outside school hours care. We have provided $10.9 million over four years to fund services targeted to rural and remote regions and disadvantaged areas. The government has maintained child-care assistance and the child-care cash redate, whilst making adjustments to remove some anomalies and to better target assistance to families with the greatest need. These adjustments will reduce subsidies to
high income families and protect low and middle income families.

I believe that Australian families, who will start to receive the benefit of the FTI election commitment in their hands from 1 January next year, will realise that this government is committed to Australian families.
