I did give my reasons for making these amendments during my speech on the second reading, so I will not belabour that point. I just wish to say again that this family tax initiative creates fundamental problems within the nature of tax laws by changing thresholds.

I will say more about the tapers which we would like to see applied by our amendments. This is the only real area of divergence from the government's scheme. While I do not think the current section 159J or the current government scheme are the best options, we have attempted to faithfully duplicate the intent of the government bill, with one exception. This exception is to provide tapers, as is usual for rebates, under 159J.

A taper provides a means to avoid the situation where, with an increase of $1 in assessable income, a taxpayer loses several hundred dollars of benefits. In the case of the family tax initiative, we have constructed the taper so that, in regard to maximum family income, the rebates phase out over the last $5,000, terminating at the government's proposed sudden‐death level. In other words, for a family with one child of 10 years, the rebate will begin to reduce at $65,000 of assessable income and disappear at $70,000 per annum. For a family with a child under
five, the additional $500 rebate begins to cut out at $60,000 and is gone by $65,000.

I will stop here to point out that the current level at which the minimum family payment cuts out is about $64,000 for a family with one child. So the $70,000 limit for this rebate is higher than that. I also point out that the old additional family payment, which is now incorporated into family payment as maximum family payment, had a taper. It begins cutting out at around $22,700 and reduces by 50c in the dollar.

The government plan imposes a spouse income limit in respect of only the $500 rebate. Under my amendments for the rebate of $500 when you have a child under five, the spouse's income would taper off at 25c in the dollar for income above the government's proposed level—that level at which the government seeks to cut out benefit—above $4,500 per annum or $86 per week.

Given the large number of women in low‐income families who may have part-time work, we do not feel that these people should be penalised with a sudden‐death cut‐off above that level. To do so runs counter to many of the recent changes in social security legislation which recognise the importance of not creating disincentives to increasing part-time work.

A loss of $500 worth of benefit would be a major disincentive to any but those with a substantial increase in income. Personally, I find this part of the scheme to be discriminatory. When the ordinary family payment assesses family income, the dependent child income, it does not assess the income of one partner relative to the other. The government bill is designed to provide benefits specifically to families where one member is dependent on another. It will discriminate against a family with two working parents in low income jobs to give a benefit to someone making more than both the two pooled parents because they have a spouse at home.

This bill is designed to foster dependency and there are no prizes for guessing which gender is supposed to be the dependent one. Fundamentally, I find this section unjust. If I thought for a moment that the other parties would support me, I would have eliminated
the spouse income test and had only the family income test. All the high income, single income people would still have received the benefit. A family with one working partner on $60,500 and a non‐working partner getting an income from a trust of $4,400 and a family income of $64,900 would still get the government $500 rebate, although they would be ineligible for minimum family payment if they had only one child.

Such a change to total family income payment would also have included all of those families who are not rich and where both partners need to work. For example, if one partner makes $25,000 per year, which is $400 per week, and their spouse makes $100 per week or $5,200 per year for a total family income of $30,200, under this government bill, this family will be excluded. They will not get a brass razoo of the $500 rebate although they are still eligible for additional family payment to low income earners.

I point to this as a very regressive and unjust aspect of the bill. It abandons many of the battlers of this country while giving largess to the rich who can afford to have only one working spouse. It is an intentional action by the government, not an oversight. It is intended to support an obsolete notion of the ideal family of the 1950s, with dad working and mum at home with kids. Coupled with the way this government is attacking wage‐earners in the workplace relations act and the way they are attacking the unemployed in social security, the jigsaw pieces fit together to create a grim picture for the future.

For child incomes, the Greens have also introduced tapers. These correspond to the current taper levels for dependents in the Income Tax Assessment Act. This is 25c in the dollar and, for the part A benefit, my amendment would start the taper at an income level $800 less than the government limit, cutting out at that limit. I have had to do it this way because the child income limit is a variable based on the Social Security Act. These limits are approximately $6,700 per annum or $129 per week for an eligible child over 16

break.para: and $6,500 per annum or $125 per week for children under 16. In respect of the $500 rebate for children under five, we would set a 50c in the dollar taper, starting $1,000 below the government's limit.

Under the government's scheme, the child income level for such infants and toddlers will be around $6,500 per annum or $125 per week for those under 16. Our proposed taper on income limits would therefore start at a child income of $5,500 per year. This is actually higher than that allowable for the child's second parent. Remember that this is a child under five.

The government proposal for the child's maximum income level is certainly not intended to benefit the poor. This particular measure is another sign of the government's agenda to create certain advantaged families. A family with a wealthy dad, non‐working mum and the ability to direct a family trust to pay mum $85 per week and a two‐year‐old baby an income of $124 per week will obviously be the big winner. Those families with two working adults both making an amount over $90 per week with a young child will be excluded from part B benefits, which were obviously intended for a selected group of well‐heeled constituents.

In summation, the rates act was clearly not designed or intended to deal with the particulars of eligibility for variations to taxation. It establishes the underlying rates. The assessment act was designed specifically to deal with application, assessment and exceptions based on personal tax variation. It was also designed as a vehicle for government benefits, incentives and disincentives in relation to taxation. It is the act that is designed to assess the tax obligation of the individual taxpayer.

The government is wrong to seek to implement its programs through changing tax thresholds. It will place a major burden on the tax office and will probably result in problems to taxpayers. It is against all efforts to simplify tax legislation and make it more logical. I urge the government to save itself problems and to adopt our amendments. I urge other non‐government senators to support my amendments and avoid making the tax legislation more unworkable and convoluted. If you
do not, I think it is possible that this legislation will prove difficult or impossible to administer. Certainly, no‐one who supports the government legislation in its current form can claim to be a friend of tax simplification.

I have tried to preserve and honour the intent of the government in my amendment. At the same time, I think the particular methods of implementing this intent have far more to do with political appearance than sensible or well‐constructed legislation. Yes, it is possible to make these changes through the rates act, just as it is possible to build a house cantilevered over a chasm on an earthquake fault line. The question remains: why do you want to do this when there are easier and more reliable options? If the government insists on pushing ahead, if the Senate insists on allowing it to do so, and if my fears are realised and government has to come back here to fix this up, I can only say that it will be on your head.

Another example is if a family enjoys property or business income that can generally be split with any family member over the age of 18. Indeed, even income from personal exertion can be split with family members through partnerships. The point that I am making—and I think Senator Faulkner should listen to this too—
—I am, Senator.

—Only the pay‐as‐you‐earn taxpayers and sole traders can income split. When you talk about opposition to income splitting, bear in mind what you are doing is denying it to the pay‐as‐you‐earn income earner. I am not suggesting that we go that way on income splitting as a general rule, but I think that the taxation system should acknowledge income sharing. It should acknowledge the number of dependants on a particular income and their expenses.
—That's not to avoid paying tax.

—I am very much against tax avoidance, but I am saying that the tax system should acknowledge income sharing. People have a natural, entirely reasonable and healthy desire to redistribute income amongst their families. Indeed, they are under a legal obligation to do so. The Family Law Act requires a spouse to share income with his or her spouse and children. The whole theory of dividing family assets upon divorce is a recognition that income and assets have been jointly enjoyed. Should we deny income splitting in that case? No, the courts accept as a recognised fact that there needs to be sharing. The courts impose that legal obligation.
—I think it is the purpose for which it is used.

—But I am saying that, instead of having a blanket criticism on income splitting, we should more fully recog
nise the income sharing which occurs within families. Any system which fails to recognise that is nothing more than a blatant and contrived system of fiscal discrimination against families. Income redistribution within families is natural, normal and a lot more efficient, frankly, than the tax transfer systems. What families redistribute amongst themselves is much greater than what a government department redistributes.

speech.para: Coming to Senator Margetts's proposals, what she is actually proposing is to put in simpler form what this bill is doing. I found very intriguing, fascinating, the excellent paper that Senator Margetts sent around. She is saying precisely to the government that this is not an increase in the tax threshold of $1,000; in effect, it is a $200 tax rebate.

I do not think the government intended that at all. It just happens that the Treasury has sorted it out that way and has given the government the bill. I am not going to support Senator Margetts's proposition, because I hope that in the end they will be able to fix the matter—maybe next year, or whenever is suitable. I noted that the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) did say that he would take on notice some comments that I made. I hope that he does and perhaps gives us an answer at some future date.

The introduction of family tax thresholds is a first, small step towards recognising the intrafamily income redistribution. It should be developed further in future legislation that comes before this parliament from this government. Families should be empowered to support each other instead of being made dependent on the tax transfer system, so far as that is possible.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
FAMILY (TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996
The bill.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
(1)
Schedule 2, item 2, page 6 (after line 19), after paragraph (c), insert:

point 1069‐B7;

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para:
(5)
Schedule 2, page 6 (line 2) to page 60 (line 16), omit "breadwinner" (wherever occurring), substitute "primary income partner".

(6)
Schedule 2, page 6 (line 2) to page 60 (line 16), omit "breadwinner's partner" (wherever occurring), substitute "lower income partner".

I have pointed out some of the ideology inherent in this bill. A particular verbal manifestation of that ideology is the insistence on the term `breadwinner'. This is not a technical term. It is not a term used anywhere else in legislation. It is slang. It is a folksy, emotive term designed to create certain images, primarily of a nostalgic interpretation of the image of a family during the Menzies era. Perhaps it is on a par with the term `homemaker' as occupation. You cannot turn back the clock.

I think the term is inappropriate, particularly in legislation. Today most families are dual income out of necessity. Both partners frequently contribute more equally to the family income. Many people cannot find full‐time work, and dual income families dependent on part‐time and/or casual employment are common and increasing in number.

The idea of `breadwinner' with all it invokes is inappropriate for many family structures. It is used here because this government is seeking to actively promote a certain structure for families, to try to impose what it sees as the traditional past on the moving frame of the present. Such imagery may have appeal for those who are 40 or older—gosh, that is me—but I think that will seem foreign to today's families with young children and adults in their early 20s. I remind senators that this is the most likely group to have children under five. This term is already probably terminally dated.

break.para: It is inappropriate to use slang terms in legislation to push ideological images of picket fences, mum in the kitchen and dad in the Holden coming home from work. We are not here for image creation; we are here for legislation. My amendments eliminate the terms `breadwinner' and `breadwinner's partner' and replace them collectively with `primary income earner' and `lower income earner'. I commend them to the chamber.

speech.speaker: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

talk.start.para: —I concur completely with those comments. It is astonishing to find a term like `breadwinner' in legislation. Senator Kemp says there may be unintended consequences from these amendments. I cannot think of any that would be worse than having appear in legislation in Australia in 1996—in the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill—the terminology `breadwinner' and `breadwinner's partner'. It is totally inappropriate. It totally fails to reflect the reality of modern families. It totally fails to reflect a greater equality of contribution to household incomes from many sources.

speech.para: I am grateful Senator Margetts has brought this to the chamber's attention. I do not think that you have to be over 40 to be comfortable with it—I am over 40 and I am very uncomfortable with it. I am very uncomfortable with any attempt to define families in this or any other way.

talk.start.para: —You aren't uncomfortable with being over 40, though.
—Nothing I can do about it, Senator Faulkner. The next one is harder.

speech.para: It is inappropriate to have the term `breadwinner'. There are, I think, inferences that are unhealthy. We are not seeking to set up any kind of family; we are seeking to reflect in legislation something that applies fairly to all kinds of families in this country.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—I would like to ask the minister to outline to the chamber what might be the consequences of this change in terminology—referred to by Senator Kernot—if these amendments were successful. I think that
would be useful for the committee at this stage.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para: —I thank the senators for their contributions. They have been interesting. I do not quail at the use of the term `breadwinner' as some others may, but I suspect that it is a term which probably has had its day or is about to have its day. It is not, of course, a sexist term, Senator. It can apply to either male or female.
—We can't afford bread any more as a result of the budget.
—Of course, you can afford a lot of bread as a result of this initiative we are bringing before the chamber.
—No net gain.
—I think the public have recognised that there have been very substantial gains already as a result of this government being in office, and more gains will flow on 1 January.

speech.para: I do not wish to say that it is terminology which may continue to appear in legislation. In view of the importance of this, we will note the comments that you have made and the strong support which you have received from senators. Because we have not had time to carefully check the bill to make sure that it does not involve some cross‐references which may cause some problems, I would prefer that it go through in its current form.

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—That is one of the most unconvincing performances that I have ever heard from a minister in this chamber. ments on. Senator Kemp, unless you can do a little better than that—and I suspect, given your track record, you probably cannot—I remain unpersuaded to support the government in this matter.

speech.para: I think the points that have been made in a serious vein by Senator Margetts and Senator Kernot about this being a 1950s term are quite valid. This is 1950s terminology. I think it is probably terminology typical of a government which would like to take us back to the 1950s.

Minister, the only substantive argument that you could have raised in your defence is that this was a term that you thought highly appropriate for the Howard government. After all, I think a person's capacity to buy bread is a bit of a lottery now that the Howard government's plans to cut incomes for the most disadvantaged people in our community are becoming very clear indeed.

I believe that the language Senator Margetts proposes is more appropriate language for the 1990s. Given the nature of your comments, Senator Kemp, I think you would need to have a more substantive case than to just argue that this amendment not be carried because it is language that has run its course. But I do think you have to make some harder yards than you did in your previous contribution if you are to convince the chamber. I invite you, if you can do that, to take the opportunity to mount a case. You are ready to do that, Senator?

talk.start.para: —I am raring to go!
—You have now been briefed. That is good. We await with interest your contribution.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para:
—I will not respond to some of the more provocative comments that Senator Faulkner made earlier in his speech. We can deal with the comments about the relative performances of two men who were
once interested in the environment at a later date. We can easily tackle that debate.

speech.para: The whole nature of an unintended consequence is that it cannot be foreseen at the particular time. But an unforeseen consequence has already emerged. The advisers have drawn my attention to the fact that the amendment as it stands would still leave the term `breadwinner' in one of the schedules. I think I am right in saying this. On page 51, schedule 2—

talk.start.para: —Page 50, it is in the heading as well.
—On page 51, schedule 2, you will note that it says:

speech.para: The breadwinner's income test applies to a breadwinner . . .

The advice that we have from the experts here is that the amendments as you have drafted them would leave, in this area, the word `breadwinner' in. With the amendment it would read: The breadwinner's income tests applies to a primary income partner . . .

All I am saying is that I think it is difficult to make legislation on the run. We have already discovered, at least on the advice I have received, that what you are proposing, because of the wording—and I am not saying the wording could not be fixed up—would still leave the word `breadwinner' in the schedule.

Senator Margetts has raised an issue which clearly has a degree of sympathy around the chamber. Despite my own love of language and with a more traditional view, I recognise that that is probably a term that may well have run its course. We have noted the comments of senators. We have already found that the amendments which have been moved would not entirely achieve the goal that they set out to achieve. I think we should pass the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill in the form which is now before the chamber without this amendment.

talk.start.para:
—Minister, you want this Family (Tax Initiative) Bill. I would rather pass it half fixed up than wait for you to bring it back fixed up, because I do not think you will. Why cannot you instruct that whole bevy of wonderful

I would rather us take the opportunity for the will of the majority of this place to fix it up now. Is it impossible?

speech.speaker: Harradine, Sen Brian

talk.start.para: —I would really hate the word `bread' to be excised from this legislation when there are a lot of people on the breadline. I would hate the word `dough' not to be part of our common usage and language. I cannot see all the fuss about `breadwinner', to be quite frank. One of my daughters is the breadwinner and her husband is the person at home, sometimes making bread actually. She makes the dough to bring home the bacon, I suppose.

speech.para: I cannot understand all the fuss about the word `breadwinner'. There are female breadwinners and there are male breadwinners. Some bring home a half loaf and others bring home the full loaf, that is true. I do not know whether `lower income partner' should have been `secondary income partner'. One is the primary income partner and the other is the secondary income partner, I suppose.

But, seriously, the word is in common usage. I do not think there is anything wrong with the word `breadwinner'. There are, as I said, female and male breadwinners. Let us not get too tied up on all of this. I really do not see much point in knocking off that word `breadwinner'.

talk.start.para: —I concur with what Senator Harradine has said. I can assure the Senate that people under the age of 40 understand what a breadwinner is. In my generation, it is not a term which is unknown. It is well understood. What we should be doing is creating legislation which has the understanding of the community. Phrases like `primary income earner' are not phrases that one would expect to hear at the pub on a Friday afternoon. They are not phrases that are in common parlance.
—Who is drinking at the pub with you?

—Senator Kernot, if you want a list of my social acquaintances you are very welcome to it. But I assure you that if you go into a pub these days, you will find as many women in there on a Friday afternoon as you will find men.
—More.

—Senator Ferguson, if you are lucky enough to go to a pub where there are more women, that is to your advantage. The point is this: we should have legislation which is colloquially understood, not legislation with long, unnecessary, artificial and bureaucratic language. That is why I think that the amendment that Senator Margetts wishes to propose is not an amendment the committee should accept.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —In light of the information that Senator Kemp has given, I wonder if the minister would be willing to come back to the committee with some proposals in relation to updating the language. He has indicated that there may be some unforeseen consequences. His advice is, I suspect, preliminary at this time. I think that is in the spirit of what you are saying, is it not, Senator Kemp?
—That is preliminary advice, yes.

—Yes, it is preliminary advice. I think we would be interested to be advised at a later stage. Obviously I do not want to delay the passage of this legislation. Perhaps the minister would be willing to give the committee a commitment that he will look at this issue and come back with an indication of what the consequences of a change to the language might be. It is something that senators could look at in, I hope, comparatively short order.

—I would like to add to that. Could the minister please reconfirm his previous remarks that he feels the starting point is that use of the term `breadwinner' is inappropriate in 1996; and that that will be the starting point for whatever discussions he needs to have with the department?
—I hope he does not. That was the point of my intervention.
—But he said it was not appropriate.
—Not without sympathy.

—I did not hear him say that it was not appropriate. He said it may be appropriate if that were sufficient for the majority of the Senate. It may not be the wish of the majority of the Senate—I do not know.
—I accept that, Senator Harradine. It may well not be.
—That is right. I am not going to the wall over it. I put the point previously as an example: my daughter makes the dough and her husband is the one at home.
—Yes, my husband cooks too. What does it prove?

—What does this prove? That is the whole point! We start off the day talking about giving us the daily bread, don't we? I do not want to have the term `bread' belittled. A breadwinner is a breadwinner whether they are female breadwinners or they are male breadwinners, for crying out loud! You say `income earners'. I like the word `breadwinners' because it is gutsy. It infers that people are out there working. They are not sitting on their backside getting income from investments or whatever. `Breadwinner' is a workers' term. I am surprised to hear Senator Faulkner suggesting that that workers' term ought to be excised from the taxation legislation.
—You heard my comments. Don't misrepresent the comments I have made.
—What you are saying is that `breadwinner' is no longer—
—I have suggested that we pass the bill and get on with it. The minister will come back to us. I am saying that we pass the bill with the word `breadwinner' in there and get on with it.

—What you are also suggesting—maybe you are not—is that the
word is past its day. I do not think it has passed its day at all.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —It was actually me who suggested it be expunged from the family tax bill. I will take all responsibility. The reason I made that suggestion is that for a long time people in the progressive community in the electorate that I believe I represent have been saying that issues like unpaid labour within the family ought to be addressed; that we should not assume the person who has got the paid job is the person who actually allows that bread to be on the table. The reality is that the contributions of all the people in a family are important. Until now we as a society have not necessarily valued unpaid work. In that sense I do not think we are actually arguing different things.

speech.para: By assuming that the person in paid work is the person who gets the bread on the table is not necessarily acknowledging the fact that in the 1990s we should be looking at the fact that the contributions of both partners are worthy; whether they are in the paid work force or in the unpaid work force, their contributions are worthy. If we use the term `breadwinner', we are actually saying that the person who got that bread on the table is the person in the paid work force. There are lots of concepts here which I am saying are outdated. It is time we moved on, so I will take all responsibility for the invective directed towards me.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para: —I wish to make what I hope are a few concluding remarks. There are clearly strong feelings on both sides of the chamber about the use of the word. I think that we should now move to pass the bill in the form that it is. I am happy to come back on an appropriate occasion to make a statement in relation to the use of `breadwinner', `primary income earner' or whatever so that the Senate itself can consider which term it prefers in relation to any future bills that come before it.

speech.para:
I think it is important that we have now detected that there are a variety of views on this issue in the chamber. We have had some advice that the amendment that was moved
will not fully meet the requirements that Senator Margetts has put to us. I think now is the time for us to move forward so that we can deliver this important bill to the Australian public.

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I just want to make a very brief contribution to correct the record, lest anyone who might be silly enough to be listening to this debate at a quarter past 12 actually took any account of what Senator Harradine said. speech.para: Let us not hold up the passage of the bill. speech.speaker: Harradine, Sen Brian

talk.start.para: —I expressed a view. I understood that Senator Faulkner, on behalf of the opposition, had indicated that the word `breadwinner' was outmoded, but it now appears that that is not the case.
—It is quite clear what I said, Senator.
—If I have in any way painted what you have said in a false manner, I apologise.
—You certainly have, Senator, and I appreciate the fact that you will have a look at it.

—I withdraw that, and apologise if that is the situation. I am not going to the wall over it. I have stood here plenty of times suggesting that action be taken to give full recognition to the contribution of non-income earning spouses.
—And the whole volunteer section of society.

I know that there might be different views about the matter. I do apologise to the committee—I was going to say for going off my brain a while ago—for a rather embellished statement.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
(7)
Schedule 2, after item 1, page 6 (before line 8), insert:
Omit "of the opposite sex".

This amendment seeks to eliminate terminology that creates gender bias within legislation. Section 4 is an entire section of several pages stipulating exactly what constitutes a member of a couple. Subsection (3) stipulates things to consider in assessing whether a couple is in a relationship. It stipulates things such as the financial aspects of the relationship, including any joint ownership of real estate or
other major assets and any joint liabilities, and any significant pooling of financial resources, especially in relation to major financial commitments.

This subsection also talks about legal obligations, the basis of sharing of day‐to‐day household expenses, the nature of the household, any joint responsibility for providing care, the living arrangements of the people, the basis on which responsibility for housework is distributed, the social aspects of the relationship, including whether the people hold themselves out as married to each other, the assessment of friends and regular associates, the basis on which the people make plans for or engage in joint social activities, any sexual relationship between the people, the nature of the people's commitment to each other, including the length of the relationship, the nature of any companionship and emotional support that the people provide to each other, whether the people consider that the relationship is likely to continue indefinitely, and whether the people see their relationship as a marriage‐like relationship.

This would seem like a very detailed description of what virtually anyone would consider to be the criteria to assess whether people are a couple in a relationship. The fly in the ointment is the introduction of a totally gratuitous and arbitrary exclusion of a whole group of people. It is primarily part of a systematic exclusion and bias against that group. In subsection 2, the definition of a member of a couple includes (b)(i), which is the subparagraph that I seek to change. Subsection 4(2)(b), which defines couples in an unmarried relationship, states:

4(2)
Subject to subsection (3), a person is a
member of a couple
for the purposes of this Act if:

(b)
all of the following conditions are met:

para.tab:
(i)
the person has a relationship with a person of the opposite sex (in this paragraph called the "
partner
");

(ii)
the person is not legally married to the partner;

(iv)
both the person and the partner are over the age of consent applicable in the State or Territory in which they live;

(v)
the person and the partner are not within a prohibited relationship for the purposes of section 23B of the
Marriage Act 1961
.

speech.para: Section 4(2)(b)(i) states that it is impossible for members of the same sex to legally be in a relationship, in spite of fulfilling all of the criteria anyone would use to assess this. This is fundamentally and solely a clause to exclude homosexuals. At this point, I believe that many of those who do not approve of homosexuality do at least recognise that members of the same sex do have relationships and, intuitively, using the criteria contained in subsection 4(3) can see and admit that, yes, these same sex people are in a relationship and those are not.

It is also widely accepted that legal systematic discrimination solely on the basis of gender preference is wrong. We have the opportunity to right that wrong. We could here and now eliminate a bit of that systematic discrimination. The effect of my amendment would be to change 4(2)(b)(i) to read:

The person has a relationship with a person (in this paragraph called the "
partner
").

It is very simple. There is a clause here which is nothing but a statement of systematic refusal to extend recognition to people because they love people of their own gender. We can eliminate that discrimination. I invite your support.

talk.start.para: —We will be opposing the amendment which has been moved by Senator Margetts. It does not actually deal with the family tax initiative. It raises many issues, and we feel that the consequences of this amendment would be very substantial. We will be opposing the amendment.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—So I can make the opposition's position absolutely clear on this: we will not be supporting the amendment. I think the amendment will actually affect the whole of
the Social Security Act, not just the family tax payment. I certainly recognise the fact that same sex couples argue they should be treated like opposite sex couples. The effect of this amendment may well actually be, in the main, to reduce social security incomes of Australians who are living in same sex relationships. I am not convinced that these effects have been properly considered in relation to this particular amendment. So that no-one misunderstands, I repeat that we will not be supporting your amendment.

—We have generally supported or moved similar amendments to this. When the minister said that this affects the whole family tax bill, yes, it does because it has a different definition of what a family is. speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the House, I welcome the President of the Senate and honourable senators to this meeting of the House of Representatives and the Senate in this chamber to hear the address by the President of the United States of America, the Honourable William Jefferson Clinton.

debate.title: ADDRESS BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

para.emphasis: The Honourable William Jefferson Clinton having been announced and escorted into the chamber—

speech.speaker: Howard, John, MP

talk.start.para:
—Mr Speaker, Madam President, this is only the second time in the
history of this parliament that the two houses have sat together to hear an address from a visiting head of state or visiting head of government. That circumstance itself is a token of the particular esteem in which the office of the Presidency of the United States of America is held by the Australian people, and it is also a markedly special relationship that exists between our two countries.

speech.para: Mr President, when the six colonies of Australia federated in 1901 to form the Commonwealth of Australia, we adopted a Westminster system of parliamentary government. But we borrowed extensively from the United States of America in relation to our other constitutional forms. We named our lower house the House of Representatives and our upper house the Senate, after the pattern of your country. We decided to assign specific powers to the central government with the residue to the state governments, after the pattern of your country. We borrowed heavily on your federal experience. The history of Australia from the parliamentary point of view has been that mixture. But out of that amalgam of British and American tracts has emerged a distinctive and characteristic Australian parliamentary democracy. It has been an echo of the aspirations of the Australian people over the long years since Federation.

There are only a very small number of countries which have continuously been democratic through the 20th century. The United States of America and Australia are two of that small and very select number of nations. For that reason, above many other reasons, your presence here today is warmly received, warmly welcomed and warmly applauded by all of the Australian people, irrespective of their political beliefs. It is rare indeed that we have an assembly of all members and senators across the party divide unanimously to welcome the leader of a great nation, a nation which has led the cause of freedom and the battle for freedom and the values we all share in common over such a long period of time.

para.break: We both belong to a robust democratic tradition. We both belong to nations that believe in individual liberty, believe in per sonal values, believe in the freedom of the press, believe in the separation of the judiciary from the legislative and the executive. For all of those reasons, and many others, you are indeed a very welcome guest.

speech.para: I hope, Mr President, that your time here in Canberra is one that you remember fondly. We certainly will. I hope both you and Mrs Clinton enjoy your time and carry with you a special recollection of your addressing this joint sitting of the parliament of the Australian people.

speech.speaker: Beazley, Kim, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, Mr President, Madam President, honourable members and senators: Mr President, you are most welcome on this historic occasion—as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) pointed out, one of only a couple—and we are very proud to be here with you. I should say that there are more than simply the government and opposition represented here. There are a number of Independent members and also members of two other political parties, the Greens and the Australian Democrats. This is a great gathering of all Australian opinion to hear you in this place, and no better forum than this.

speech.para: George Schultz once said to me, `How could anybody spend $1 billion on a building?' We took him through the building and he worked out how we managed to spend it. It is a place of which we are enormously proud and is a great symbol of our nation and the unity of our nation and the hopes and aspirations of our people. It has within it a very specific Australian design.

It is of course not the first time—your visit here or the visit of your predecessor George Bush—that there has been the involvement of the United States in our parliamentary process, and I think it is useful to reflect on that. Throughout World War II we did have a number of parliamentary briefings given by General Douglas MacArthur, who is a man whose name rings in the halls of fame of this nation and a name that is remembered with gratitude. This brings to mind the fact that we ought to in this place appreciate through yourself the role of your nation over the last 50 years or so of international history.

break.para: You now preside over a nation which has produced probably the most unselfish gesture that any nation has in recorded history—that is, your people have been prepared to lay themselves on the line when they could have been secure in isolation and to risk for themselves nuclear devastation on behalf of their friends. It ought not go unrecorded that we do appreciate that.

It should be said that that sat lightly on this country because I do not think we have ever been in recent times likely to have enemies that would cause the United States to risk that nuclear devastation in assisting us. Nevertheless, we have thought it important for ourselves to play a part in that. I have often argued, particularly when I was the Minister for Defence, that we have never been consumers of American security except in that one period.

I also like to point out to my American colleagues that General Douglas MacArthur had more Australian troops under his command until late 1943 than American. His great victories early in the war in New Guinea were fought substantially with Australian troops. He set that matter at rest and changed the ratios in the Philippines. But, until that point in time, there had been a very substantial contribution. We have made our contribution over those years, too.

We very much appreciate the remarks I heard you make in your press conference—that you had praise for the Australian government and successive Australian governments for the role they now wish to play in removing from the American people and the world that terrible obligation. Your praise for the role of our government recently in the comprehensive test ban arrangement was very welcome on all sides of politics here, as is your commitment to ensuring that your people and the world generally have that horror removed from them.

para.break: You have been a man who has exercised leadership in this region—whose leadership we all count on. You go from here with our Prime Minister to APEC—a forum the leadership component of which you had so much to do with in initiating. That forum is now broadening its wings from simply a consider ation of economic matters, critical as those are, to broader regional considerations.

break.para: We have always sought American engagement in this region. We have never always agreed with you on the things that you have chosen to do in that time, but we have always sought it because we have always believed that at the end of the day the values we share are the same. Those values are decent human values. Those values are egalitarian values that recognise the rights of all people of all backgrounds. Those values are values which at the end of the day ensure world peace and ensure decent living standards. So it is a privilege for me to stand here today on behalf my party to welcome you.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, your address today to members and senators in this chamber is a significant occasion in the history of our federal parliament in this great nation of ours and for the people of Australia. It gives me great pleasure to invite you to address assembled senators and members.

para.emphasis: Whereupon honourable members and honourable senators rose in their places and applauded.

talk.start.para: —Mr Prime Minister, Mr Speaker, Madam President of the Senate, Leader of the Opposition, all the members of the Senate and House of Representatives, and ladies and gentlemen here assembled: let me begin, Prime Minister, by thanking you and the people of Canberra and all of Australia for the absolutely tremendous welcome that Hillary, I and the entire American delegation have received. I know this is called the land down under, but after only a day we all feel like we are on top of the world, and I thank you for that.

break.para: I appreciate the opportunity to speak to you in this great hall of democracy. Your Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies was one of the very few world leaders to address our United States Congress twice. I give you that fact as a point of interest not as a pitch for a return engagement here!
Forty-one years ago this year he said to our people:

We have with your great country as a result of war as well as of peace a tie which I believe to be unbreakable and a degree of affectionate simple understanding which I do not believe can be surpassed between any two countries of the world.

Today, 41 years later, the Prime Minister's insight still holds. The ties between us span more than 200 years. In 1792 an American ship—named, for brotherhood, the
Philadelphia
—arrived at Port Jackson with supplies that helped to save the colonists from starvation. Former Prime Minister Fraser noted that the beef that the
Philadelphia
carried had been on board for nine months—`well cured' he called it.

Well, my friends, two centuries later, our friendship, tested in war and seasoned in peace, has also become well cured. Our people have built bridges of commerce and culture, friendship and trust, reaching over the greatest expanse of ocean on earth. The United States is proud to be Australia's largest foreign investor and largest trading partner. We are also proud of the wars we have fought together and the peace we have fought to sustain together.

The great diversity of our ties was born of shared experience and common values. Our pioneers both settled vast frontiers and built free nations across entire continents. In one another, I really believe we see a distant mirror of our better selves: reflections of liberty and decency, of openness and vitality.

In this century, our bonds have truly been forged in the fires of wars—war after war after war. Together we carried liberty's torch in the darkest nights of the 20th century. My message to you today is that we must embrace the dawn of this new century together and we must make the most of it together. We carried a torch through the night; now we can create the dawn our children deserve.

For Australia's strength and sacrifice through these many struggles, for your fierce love of liberty and your unfailing friendship to the United States, the American people thank you. And the American people look forward with you to this new era of freedom and possibilities. After all, our nations are at peace; our economies are strong; the ideas we have struggled for—freedom of religion,
speech and assembly, open markets, tolerance—are more and more the habits of all humanity.

For the first time in all history, two‐thirds of all the nations on this earth and more than half the people alive today are ruled by governments picked by their own people. The rigid blocks and barriers that too long defined the world are giving way to an era of breath‐taking expansion of information technology and information. And because of these things we now have a chance, greater than any generation of people who ever lived before us, to give more and more people the opportunity to realise their God‐given potential to live their own dreams, not someone else's plan.

But this chance we have is nothing more than that. It is a chance, not a guarantee. For all its promise, we know that this new century will not be free of peril and therefore we know that our freedom still requires our responsibility. Nations and peoples still will be tempted to fight wars for territory or out of ethnic, religious or racial hatred.

As I told the American people over and over again during the recent election campaign, it was literally heartbreaking to me to think of how much of their time I had to spend dealing with people who still believe it is all right to murder each other and each other's children because of their racial, their religious, their ethnic, their tribal differences. We must stand against that, and the example of how we live together must be a rebuke to that in the 21st century.

Make no mistake about it, there is a nexus of new threats—terrorists, rogue states, international criminals, drug traffickers. They too menace our security, and they will do more of it in the new century. They will be all the more lethal if they gain access to weapons of mass destruction, whether nuclear, chemical or biological.

para.break: Because of our size, our strength, our prosperity and the power of our example, Australia and the United States have a special responsibility not only to seize the opportunities but to move against the new threats of the 21st century. Together we can reduce even more the danger of weapons of mass destruc tion. We can take the fight to the terrorists and the drug traffickers; we can extend the reach of free and fair trade; we can advance democracy around the world; and, yes, we can prove that free societies can embrace the economic and social changes and the ethnic, racial and religious diversity this new era brings and come out stronger and freer than ever.

break.para: The threat of nuclear weapons born a half century ago finally is diminishing as a new century begins. The United States and Russia are reducing our arsenals, pointing our weapons away from one another and working to safeguard nuclear materials and facilities. Every single Australian should be very proud of the role your country has played in guiding the world toward a more secure future. You helped lead the fight to extend the non-proliferation treaty. Your determined diplomacy brought the comprehensive test ban treaty to reality and the world to the verge of banning all nuclear testing for all time. Every nation is in your debt for that achievement. On behalf again of the people of the United States, I say thank you.

Now we must pursue together our remaining arms control agenda for the reductions in Russia's and America's arsenals, once Russia ratifies START II: a chemical weapons convention, so that our troops never face poison gas on the battlefield and our people never fall victim to it in a terrorist attack; a stronger biological weapons convention, so that disease is never used as a weapon of war; and a worldwide ban on landmines, so that all our children can walk with confidence on the earth beneath them.

As we deal with these challenges to our security, we must recognise the new ones which are emerging and the new approaches they require. Terrorism, international crime and drug trafficking are forces of destruction that have no tolerance for national borders. Together we must show zero tolerance for them. That means putting pressure on rogue states, not doing business with them. It is very difficult to do business by day with people who kill innocent civilians by night.

It means giving no aid and quarter to terrorists who slaughter the innocent and drug
traffickers who poison our children. It means, in short, pursuing a concerted strategy—intelligence and police cooperation worldwide, coordinated legal action in every country to stop money laundering, shutting down grey markets for guns and false documents, and increasing extraditions. It means security coordination in our airports and airplanes, and giving, each in our own nations, our law enforcement officials the tools they need to cooperate and to succeed.

The measure of our people's security includes not only their physical safety, however, but, as we all know, their economic well-being. Our two countries have led in opening markets around the world and we can be pleased with our progress. Through GATT, the WTO, APEC and literally hundreds of smaller accords, we are moving to extend the reach of free and fair trade. But we can do more, issue by issue, agreement by agreement.

I am determined to work with Congress in my second term to move ahead boldly on market opening initiatives around the world. Decades from now I want people to say that our generation rose to the challenge of creating a new open trading system for the 21st century. If we do, more people will have good jobs and better lives as they share in humanity's genius for progress.

Over the long term we can best advance the security and prosperity we seek by expanding and strengthening not only trade but the community of free nations. The tide of democracy is now running strong and deep. Consider this: in just the past few weeks, the people of Lithuania, Bulgaria, Romania, Moldova, Nicaragua and Thailand have freely elected their leaders—a prospect literally unimaginable not very long ago. In my own hemisphere every nation but one has raised freedom's flag. In central Europe and in Russia, Ukraine and the other new independent states, the forces of reform have earned our respect and deserve our continued support. For the first time since the rise of nation states on the continent of Europe it is literally conceivable that we have an opportunity—a real and tangible opportunity—to build a continent that is democratic, undivided and at
peace. It has never been possible before, and together we can achieve it now.

I know that some people on both sides of the Pacific are concerned that America's continuing involvement with Europe and our intense renewed involvement with our neighbours in Latin America will lead to disengagement from the Asia-Pacific region. They are wrong. Mr Prime Minister, if I could borrow your eloquent phrase—at least I am giving you credit, which we politicians do not often do—the United States does not need to choose between our history and our geography. We need not choose between Europe and Asia. In a global economy with global security challenges, America must look to the east no less than to the west. Our security demands it. After all, we fought three wars here in living memory. The Cold War's last frontier lies now on the Korean peninsula. The region as a whole is in the midst of profound change—so our security demands it; our prosperity requires it.

One-third of our exports and more than two million American jobs depend upon our trade with Asia. Over the next decade, Asia's remarkable growth will mean ever expanding markets for those who can compete in them. Our future cannot be secure if Asia's future is in doubt. As we enter the 21st century, therefore I say to you that not only has America been but she is and will remain a Pacific power. We want America's involvement and influence to provide the stability among nations which is necessary for the people of the Asia-Pacific region to make the routines of normal life a reality and to spur the economic progress that will benefit all of us.

To meet those challenges of stability we are now pursuing three objectives: stronger alliances, deeper engagement with China and a larger community of democracies. First, we share the view of almost every nation in Asia that a strong American security presence remains the bedrock for regional stability. We will maintain about 100,000 troops across the Pacific, just as we maintain about 100,000 troops in Europe. We will keep them well trained, well equipped and well prepared. We
will continue to revitalise our core alliances, both bilaterally and regionally.

These efforts, let me say clearly, are not directed against any nation. They are intended to advance security and stability for everyone so that we can grow together and work together, all of us, in the new century. Our alliance with the democratic, prosperous Japan has been one of the great achievements of the postwar period. Last spring, after more than a year's hard study and work, Prime Minister Hashimoto and I signed a new security charter. Japan's continued support for our military presence and even closer links between our armed forces will enable us to deepen our cooperation on behalf of peace and stability in this region and beyond.

With our close ally in South Korea we are working to reduce tensions on the Korean peninsula that threaten all of North-East Asia. We must give new momentum now to the four‐party peace talks President Kim and I proposed last spring, and we must continue our work to dismantle North Korea's frozen nuclear program. We are reinforcing our security ties with the Philippines and Thailand while multiplying the power of our troops through greater access to regional military facilities.

Finally, and simply put, the defence links between the United States and Australia have never been stronger in peacetime. Mr Prime Minister and members of parliament, the agreements our foreign and defence ministers signed this summer in Sydney authorised the largest exercises involving our troops since World War II. American marines will soon begin training in northern Australia, and we are deepening our already strong security cooperation. Today I say again with utter confidence: our alliance is not just for this time; it is for all time.

As we work nation to nation let us continue to build a new architecture for regional security as well—an architecture through ASEAN that will strengthen our ability to confront common challenges. Already this effort is helping to defuse tensions in the South China Sea and to dispel distrust across the region. We must pursue it to its full potential.

Our second stabilising objective is deeper engagement with China. The direction China takes in years to come, the way it defines its greatness in the future, will help to decide whether the next century is one of conflict or cooperation. The emergence of a stable, open and prosperous China, a strong China confident of its place in the world and willing to assume its responsibilities as a great nation, is in our deepest interest.

True cooperation is both possible and plainly productive. We worked closely with China to extend the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and to secure the passage of the comprehensive test ban treaty. We joined to shore up peace in Cambodia and increase stability on the Korean peninsula. We are making progress together on some tough issues, from nuclear technology to intellectual property rights.

The United States and China will continue to have important differences, especially in the area of human rights, and we will continue to discuss them candidly. But, by working together where possible and dealing with our differences openly and respectfully where necessary, we can deepen our dialogue and add to Asia's stability. I look forward to doing just that when I meet for the fourth time with President Jung in the Philippines next week.

The third part of our work for stability is support for the advance of democracy. Our two nations know that democracy comes in many forms. Neither of us seeks to impose our own vision on others, but we also share the conviction that some basic rights are universal and we have to decide whether we believe that. I believe that everywhere people aspire to be treated with dignity, to give voice to their opinions, to choose their own leaders. We have seen these dreams realised in the democratic odyssey of the Asia-Pacific, from Japan to South Korea, to Thailand and Mongolia.

In this century we have sacrificed many of our sons and daughters, your nation and ours, for the cause of freedom, and so we must continue to speak for the cause of freedom in this new age of commerce and trade and technology. We must push repressive regimes
in places like Burma to pursue reconciliation in genuine political dialogue. We must assist new democracies like Cambodia by encouraging the development of political parties and institutions. We know that the freer and better educated people are, the more creative they become, the better able they are to compete, the more able they are to satisfy each other's deepest wants and needs. We can look at the economic vitality of the Philippines, Thailand, Taiwan and South Korea to see the proof of this assertion.

As stability extends its reach and strengthens its grip, the Pacific may finally be able to live up to its name. In Cambodia farmers once again till the land that had become horrific killing fields. In Vietnam school children can worry more about their exams than about the war. From Bangkok to Manila, power is no longer used against the people; it is in the hands of the people.

A generation ago it was hard to imagine how rapidly freedom could come to these nations, how rapidly their economies could grow. But freed from the threat of war, unleashed by their new-found freedoms, the people of this region have built among the greatest success stories the world has ever seen. They have transformed economic wastelands into powerful engines for growth; enriched the lives of millions by harnessing the technology of change. Today the economies of the Asia-Pacific are clearly the most dynamic on earth.

para.break: More than seven million Americans trace their roots to Asia. Five of our states touch the Pacific. We are inexorably linked to the promise of the Asia-Pacific region. That is why in the first year of my term I sought to elevate the APEC forum that began right here in Canberra into the first ever meeting of Asia and Pacific leaders. At our inaugural summit in Seattle, working closely with your former Prime Minister Paul Keating, we agreed to give this extraordinarily diverse region a common goal: to work as a community of nations committed to economic integration. A year later in Jakarta we made a historic commitment: free trade and investment in the region by 2020. Some said that was an illusory vision, but already that vision is becom ing a blueprint—a blueprint taking shape as concrete commitments.

break.para: At next week's leaders meeting, Prime Minister Howard and I hope and expect that APEC will give a boost to specific market opening initiatives. For me, I hope that means unshackling trade in computers, semiconductors and telecommunications—the high-tech sectors of the future. We have an opportunity to set an example for the rest of the world, and we ought to seize it. If we do, the nations of the region will benefit—those who provide the services and those who receive them.

Progress, after all, is not yet everyone's partner, and we have a responsibility to open the doors of opportunity to those who remain outside the global economy. For example, some two-thirds of the people on our planet have no access to a telephone. I found that hard to believe when I saw so many of your fellow citizens with their cellphones in their hands as I drove up and down your streets.

More than half the people of the world are two days walk from a telephone. They are totally disconnected from the communications and information revolution that is the present vehicle for human progress and possibility. If we add their creative energies to the mix which now exists, of course they will gain skills and jobs and greater wealth, but we also will benefit from the higher growth rates, from the expanded markets and from the increasing likelihood that those people will find peaceful rather than war-like ways to release their energies. We can do this if we have the courage not to retreat but instead to compete.
At this year's meeting at APEC, and everywhere I go, I will also deliver again a simple, loud and clear message: the United States is more determined than ever to create an Asian

Pacific community of shared efforts, shared benefits and shared destiny. The interests that compel our engagement have grown, not shrunk, and so has our commitment to a Pacific future. We know from our past that we can succeed, that we are equal to the difficulties ahead.
I began the day by quoting Prime Minister Menzies, so let me conclude by returning to his words. He said:

The world needs every scrap of democratic strength that can be found in it because nobody, however optimistic, need underestimate the measure or the character of danger that always confronts us. It is not merely our privilege to be strong, it is our duty to be strong.

The world needs Australia. The world needs the United States. It needs us together as partners and friends and allies. We have stood together in the hard times as partners and friends. Let us stand together and work together now for a new future of peace and possibility that extends to our children and our grandchildren and to all the children of the world.
May God bless Australia, the United States and the great friendship between our nations. Thank you very much.

The Honourable William Jefferson Clinton having left the chamber—

talk.start.para: —I thank members and senators for their attendance. The House stands adjourned until tomorrow at 9.30 a.m. I hereby declare this meeting of the House of Representatives and the Senate concluded.
